metadata.titleEn: Seismic velocity reduction and accelerated recovery due to earthquakes on the Longmenshan fault (2000-2014)
metadata.description:
This data set is collected from the supplementary information part of the paper: Pei, S.P., Niu, F.L., Ben-Zion, Y., Sun, Q., Liu, Y.B., Xue, X.T., Su,J.R., & Shao, Z.G. (2019). Seismic velocity reduction and accelerated recovery due to earthquakes on the Longmenshan fault. Nature Geoscience. 12. 387-392. doi:10.1038/s41561-019-0347-1. 
This paper studies the structural evolution process of The Longmenshan fault zone located at a pronounced topographic boundary between the eastern margin of the Tibetan plateau and the western Sichuan basin. With the observations on coseismic velocity reductions and the healing phases, it is found that the healing phase of Wenchuan earthquake fracture zone accelerated significantly in response to the Lushan earthquake.
This data set contains 3 tables, table names and content are as follows:
Data list: The data name list of the rest tables;
t1: Data of the four periods (befor Wenchuan earthquake, after Wenchuan earthquake, before Lushan earthquake, after Lushan earthquake);
t2: The average velocities with error in Figure 2 in the paper for Wenchuan earthquake (WCEQ) and Lushan earthquake (LSEQ) area.
See attachments for data details: Supplementary information.pdf, Seismic velocity reduction and accelerated recovery due to earthquakes on the Longmenshan fault.pdf.
metadata.instructions: The data is named by the paper, it can be viewed and edited by Excel software of Microsoft Office.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of seismic velocity changes observed in the Longmenshan fault zone during different earthquake periods?
Feature Specification.Answer: seismic velocity reduction during co-seismic events, accelerated recovery post-seismic, average velocities with error margins

Quantification.Question: How many data tables are included in a dataset examining seismic velocity reduction and recovery on the Longmenshan fault?

Definition.Question: What does 'seismic velocity reduction' mean in the context of seismic data collection and analysis?
Definition.Answer: Seismic velocity reduction refers to the observed decrease in the speed at which seismic waves travel through the Earth's crust in the aftermath of an earthquake. This phenomenon can be indicative of changes in subsurface geological structures and is typically measured using seismic data collected before and after seismic events. In the context of seismic data collection and analysis, understanding seismic velocity reduction involves identifying variations in wave speeds to assess the impact of seismic activity on fault zones and their subsequent recovery processes.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for monitoring seismic velocity changes on the Longmenshan fault during the Wenchuan and Lushan earthquakes compare in terms of capturing co-seismic and post-seismic phenomena?
Comparison.Answer: The research on the Longmenshan fault utilized observational data to capture seismic velocity reductions and recovery phenomena, focusing on four distinct periods: before the Wenchuan earthquake, after the Wenchuan earthquake, before the Lushan earthquake, and after the Lushan earthquake. This approach allowed for a detailed comparison of the co-seismic and post-seismic processes in the fault region, highlighting the significant acceleration of healing in the Wenchuan earthquake rupture zone following the Lushan earthquake.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the structural evolution of fault zones from observed patterns in seismic velocity reduction and recovery following significant earthquakes?
Interpretation.Answer: Observations of seismic velocity reduction and recovery in fault zones indicate that significant earthquakes, such as those on the Longmenshan fault, can cause a notable decrease in seismic wave velocity, and these zones can experience an accelerated healing process post-earthquake. This suggests that earthquakes may temporarily alter the structural integrity of the fault, leading to changes in the material properties that are detectable through seismic velocity measurements. The accelerated recovery observed in the Wenchuan earthquake rupture area following the Lushan earthquake implies a dynamic interaction between seismic events and the ongoing healing mechanisms within the fault structure.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the changes in seismic velocity during and after major earthquakes on the Longmenshan fault?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The changes in seismic velocity are influenced by the structural evolution of the Longmenshan fault during significant earthquakes. Observations of co-seismic velocity reduction and post-seismic recovery highlight the impact of seismic events such as the Wenchuan and Lushan earthquakes. These changes are affected by the stress release during earthquakes and the subsequent healing of the fault.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on the understanding of seismic activity if data collection methods accurately capture seismic velocity reduction and accelerated recovery in fault zones?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Accurately capturing seismic velocity reduction and accelerated recovery can enhance the understanding of fault zone dynamics, revealing the structural evolution during and after significant seismic events. It may provide insights into the healing process of earthquake rupture areas, potentially improving earthquake prediction models and contributing to more effective risk assessments in seismic-prone regions.
